questions.text: In the clinical vignette provided, a patient presents with painful vesicles on the ear and facial nerve palsy. Which diagnosis most accurately accounts for these findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Ramsay Hunt syndrome due to involvement of the geniculate ganglion

options.label: B
options.text: Ramsay Hunt syndrome due to involvement of the basal ganglia

options.label: C
options.text: Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome with basal ganglia involvement

options.label: D
options.text: Gradenigo's syndrome with geniculate ganglion involvement

questions.correct_answer: A. Ramsay Hunt syndrome due to involvement of the geniculate ganglion
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ramsay Hunt syndrome due to involvement of the geniculate ganglion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ramsay Hunt syndrome is characterized by painful vesicles in the ear (herpes zoster oticus) and facial nerve palsy due to the reactivation of varicella-zoster virus in the geniculate ganglion.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with diabetes presents with severe ear pain, otorrhea resistant to antibiotic treatment, and granulation tissue in the external auditory canal (EAC). Facial nerve palsy is also noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Malignant otitis externa.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malignant otitis externa is the likely diagnosis in a diabetic patient presenting with severe ear pain, resistant otorrhea, granulation tissue in the EAC, and facial nerve palsy.

questions.text: A patient undergoing syringing to remove ear wax experiences a syncopal episode when the tip of the syringe touches the ear canal. Which nerve is most likely responsible for this reflex syncope?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arnold's nerve.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stimulation of Arnold's nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve, during ear syringing can cause a vagal reflex syncope.

questions.text: Based on the otoscopic image provided, how would you classify the degree of tympanic membrane retraction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Grade 1.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Grade 1 indicates a slight retraction without involvement of the ossicles or deeper middle ear structures.

questions.text: The image provided depicts a structure of the middle ear. Which of the following is this structure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Malleus.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malleus is the ossicle of the middle ear depicted in the image, distinguishable by its characteristic components, including the head, neck, lateral process, and manubrium.

questions.text: A primipara has noticed a progressive hearing loss during pregnancy. Rinne's test is negative bilaterally, and Weber's test lateralizes to the right. Otoscopic examination reveals normal tympanic membranes, and audiometry indicates a dip at 2000 Hz in bone conduction. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Stapedotomy.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stapedotomy is the treatment of choice for otosclerosis presenting with conductive hearing loss and normal tympanic membranes, especially when audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in bone conduction.

questions.text: A female patient presents with conductive hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals an intact tympanic membrane with a red, bulging mass visible behind it. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glomus tumor.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A glomus tumor (paraganglioma) can present as a red, bulging mass behind an intact tympanic membrane and is a common cause of conductive hearing loss with visible vascular mass behind the tympanic membrane.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with neck lymphadenopathy presents with a left ear examination showing a dull tympanic membrane, hearing loss, and tinnitus. Tympanometry reveals a Type B curve. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a likely diagnosis in an elderly patient presenting with neck lymphadenopathy, dull tympanic membrane, hearing loss, tinnitus, and a flat tympanogram, indicative of Eustachian tube obstruction or middle ear effusion.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a history of hearing impairment for the past few months. Otoscopic examination reveals the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Otitis Media with Effusion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otitis media with effusion is a condition causing hearing impairment in children, characterized by the presence of effusion in the middle ear without signs of acute infection.

questions.text: In the image provided, which surgical retractor is shown?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Perkins retractor.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Perkins retractor is a surgical instrument used in otolaryngology for retracting tissue in ear surgeries.

questions.text: Which embryonic structure gives rise to the utricle?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pars superior.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Utricle, a structure involved in the sense of balance, develops from the superior part of the otic vesicle in embryogenesis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with decreased hearing predominantly in the lower frequencies, with involvement of the basilar membrane noted. Which of the following anatomical structures is located near the site of pathology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Helicotrema.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Helicotrema is situated at the apex of the cochlea, near the basilar membrane, and is associated with the detection of low-frequency sounds.

questions.text: What is the primary function of the semicircular canals within the vestibular system?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Detection of angular acceleration.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Semicircular canals are responsible for detecting angular acceleration, which is essential for balance and spatial orientation.

questions.text: Identify the test where this pattern of waves are found ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is the test that produces specific waves reflecting the neural responses of the auditory pathway in the brainstem.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, and tinnitus in her right ear. These symptoms have been occurring periodically for several months. A diagnosis of Meniere's disease is suspected. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Low-sodium diet and diuretics.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial treatment for Meniere's disease typically involves a low-sodium diet and diuretics to reduce the volume and pressure of endolymphatic fluid in the inner ear.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. On physical examination, you notice she has poor balance and fails the Rinne test on the affected side. What is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis of an acoustic neuroma?

options.label: B
options.text: Computed Tomography (CT) scan of the head

options.label: C
options.text: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) with contrast of the internal auditory canal

questions.correct_answer: C. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) with contrast of the internal auditory canal
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) with contrast of the internal auditory canal.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The preferred method to confirm the diagnosis of an acoustic neuroma is Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) with contrast of the internal auditory canal, due to its detailed visualization of the area where these tumors occur.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus. An audiometry test shows a speech discrimination score of 75%, and the short increment sensitivity index (SISI) test reveals a score of 80%. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cochlear lesion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A cochlear lesion in a patient with unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus reveals a reduced speech discrimination score and a high SISI score during an audiometric testing.

questions.text: A surgeon while operating for intractable BPPV has accidentally cut its parent nerve. Which other structure is supposed to lose its sensory supply?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Maculae in the saccule.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sensory nerve innervating the posterior semicircular canal in cases of BPPV also innervates the maculae in the saccule, and cutting this nerve would result in loss of sensory input to both structures.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a chronic ear discharge and a recent onset of right-sided facial weakness. Otoscopic examination reveals a retraction pocket in the right tympanic membrane filled with keratin debris. Imaging studies confirm the presence of a mass in the mastoid segment of the temporal bone, consistent with cholesteatoma. Which of the following is the most immediate concern related to his facial weakness?

options.label: C
options.text: Facial nerve compression due to cholesteatoma

questions.correct_answer: C. Facial nerve compression due to cholesteatoma
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Facial nerve compression due to cholesteatoma.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholesteatoma can lead to facial nerve compression, especially when it invades the mastoid segment of the temporal bone, resulting in facial weakness. This complication is a surgical emergency and needs prompt intervention to prevent permanent damage to the facial nerve.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of head trauma after falling on their side. They are experiencing hearing loss and bloody otorrhea. Based on the mechanism of injury shown in the uploaded image, which type of temporal bone fracture is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Longitudinal fracture.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A longitudinal fracture of the temporal bone is based on the patient's symptoms and the mechanism of injury involving a blow to the parietal or temporal region.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of chronic otitis media presents with hearing loss. On examination, the Rinne test is falsely negative. Which of the following could explain this finding?

options.label: A
options.text: Profound sensorineural hearing loss in the tested ear

options.label: B
options.text: Mild conductive hearing loss in the tested ear

options.label: C
options.text: Normal hearing in the non-tested ear

options.label: D
options.text: Eustachian tube dysfunction in the non-tested ear

questions.correct_answer: A. Profound sensorineural hearing loss in the tested ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Profound sensorineural hearing loss in the tested ear.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A false negative Rinne test, suggests conductive hearing loss when sensorineural loss is present, can occur in cases of profound sensorineural hearing loss in the tested ear due to sound being perceived in the contralateral ear through bone conduction.

questions.text: Identify the type of hearing loss seen here
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mixed

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An audiogram helps to distinguish mixed hearing loss, which is characterized by elevated bone conduction thresholds above normal and a significant air-bone gap indicating both sensorineural and conductive components.

questions.text: Lacrimal gland is present in which wall of orbit?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Roof

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lacrimal gland is located in the roof of the orbit, where it functions to produce the aqueous layer of the tear film.

questions.text: Identify the abnormality that is not seen in the given picture

options.label: D
options.text: Erosion of floor of the orbit

questions.correct_answer: D. Erosion of floor of the orbit
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Erosion of floor of the orbit

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Evaluate a CT scan of the paranasal sinuses to identify common anatomical variants and pathologies such as concha bullosa, deviated nasal septum, and turbinate hypertrophy, and differentiate these from more serious conditions such as erosion of orbital structures.

questions.text: The structures marked with arrows in the CT image are most consistent with:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Haller cells.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Haller cells on a CT scan are seen as ethmoidal air cells that extend into the floor of the orbit and are situated adjacent to the maxillary sinus.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the picture is primarily used for:

options.label: C
options.text: Both nasal bone reduction and septal reduction

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Septal reduction.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Asch forceps is an instrument used for septal reduction procedures in otorhinolaryngology, distinct from instruments used for nasal bone reduction.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false with respect to Woodruff's area?

options.label: A
options.text: Venous plexus is present in this area.

options.label: B
options.text: It is situated at the posteroinferior part of the lateral wall of the nose.

options.label: C
options.text: Most common site for epistaxis in the elderly.

options.label: D
options.text: Anastomoses of 4 major arteries occur here.

questions.correct_answer: D. Anastomoses of 4 major arteries occur here.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anastomoses of 4 major arteries occur here.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Woodruff's area contains a venous plexus and is located at the posteroinferior part of the lateral nasal wall, and that it is a potential site for posterior epistaxis, especially in the elderly.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with a long-standing history of nasal crusting, foul-smelling nasal discharge, and a sensation of nasal obstruction. She has been diagnosed with atrophic rhinitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Saline nasal irrigations.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary treatment for atrophic rhinitis involves maintaining nasal moisture and cleanliness, with saline nasal irrigations being the most appropriate initial management to hydrate the nasal mucosa and remove crusts.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with chronic sinusitis, productive cough, and recurrent chest infections since childhood. A chest X-ray shows dextrocardia. Which combination of findings is most likely to be present in this patient, suggesting a diagnosis of Kartagener syndrome?

options.label: B
options.text: Situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis

options.label: D
options.text: Asthma, nasal polyps, and aspirin sensitivity

questions.correct_answer: B. Situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The classic triad of Kartagener syndrome, includes situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis, due to defects in ciliary function.

questions.text: Among the options provided, which fungal infection is most commonly observed in the paranasal sinuses?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aspergillosis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspergillosis is the most common fungal infection of the paranasal sinuses, which can present in various forms, ranging from allergic responses to invasive disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with persistent nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip after previous functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS). Diagnostic nasal endoscopy (DNE) shows blocked ostia and mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Repeat surgery.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with sinus symptoms and blocked ostia after FESS, if medical management fails, the next best step is often repeat surgical intervention to physically address the obstruction and improve drainage.

questions.text: In the clinical scenario shown, the nipple is being used for which condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Choanal atresia.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The use of a nipple in a newborn with choanal atresia facilitates oral breathing, due to the blockage of the nasal passage that is characteristic of this congenital condition.

questions.text: Which of the following laryngeal cartilages is most likely to be calcified?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Arytenoid.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Arytenoid cartilages, being composed of hyaline cartilage, are the most likely among the laryngeal cartilages listed to undergo calcification, in contrast to those composed of elastic cartilage, which are less prone to such changes.

questions.text: From the image provided, which numbered structures are parts of the hypopharynx?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 3, 5, 6.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anatomical components of the hypopharynx, include the pyriform fossa, the posterior pharyngeal wall and the postcricoid area.

questions.text: A professional singer presents with a neck swelling that appears during performances and subsides at rest. On examination, the swelling emits a crackling sound when compressed. Given the patient's occupation and clinical presentation, a CT scan of the neck was performed. Based on the imaging findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Laryngocele.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A laryngocele is an air-filled dilation of the saccule of the laryngeal ventricle, often exacerbated by activities that increase intralaryngeal pressure, and identifiable on imaging as an air-containing structure associated with the larynx.

questions.text: Which nerve provides sensory innervation to the larynx below the vocal folds (glottis)?

options.label: A
options.text: Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve

options.label: B
options.text: External branch of superior laryngeal nerve

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recurrent laryngeal nerve provides sensory innervation to the laryngeal mucosa below the vocal folds and motor innervation to most of the intrinsic muscles of the larynx.

questions.text: A patient who underwent a total thyroidectomy is experiencing respiratory distress and cannot be safely extubated. Which condition is most likely responsible for this postoperative complication?

options.label: A
options.text: Injury to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve

questions.correct_answer: C. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury during thyroidectomy can result in bilateral vocal cord paralysis and respiratory distress, often manifesting as difficulty with extubation due to airway obstruction.

questions.text: The radiological sign depicted in the image is typically associated with:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acute Epiglottitis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The thumbprint sign on a lateral neck radiograph is a classic indicator of acute epiglottitis, which is a potential airway emergency due to the risk of obstruction from epiglottal swelling.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with confirmed respiratory papillomatosis presents with progressive hoarseness and stridor. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Microlaryngeal surgery with CO2 laser excision

questions.correct_answer: C. Microlaryngeal surgery with CO2 laser excision
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Microlaryngeal surgery with CO2 laser excision.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The treatment of choice for respiratory papillomatosis is microlaryngeal surgery with CO2 laser excision to remove papillomas and alleviate symptoms like hoarseness and stridor.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with inspiratory stridor that worsens with agitation but improves when prone. The diagnosis of laryngomalacia is suspected. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Observation and reassurance.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Most cases of laryngomalacia in infants are mild and self-resolve as the child grows. Observation and reassurance are the appropriate management strategies for mild cases, with surgery reserved for more severe presentations.

questions.text: A full-term neonate presents with biphasic stridor and has been diagnosed with congenital subglottic stenosis after radiographic evaluation showed a subglottic diameter of less than 4mm. The stenosis is estimated to be 60% of the subglottic space. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate laryngotracheal reconstruction with cartilage grafts

questions.correct_answer: B. Endoscopic dilatation or laser excision
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endoscopic dilatation or laser excision.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In congenital subglottic stenosis with a Grade II obstruction, endoscopic dilatation or laser excision is often the treatment of choice, whereas conservative management is considered for Grade I, and more invasive procedures are reserved for Grades III and IV.

questions.text: Following a total laryngectomy, a patient wishes to explore options for voice rehabilitation. Which of the following methods is most effective for speech rehabilitation?
questions.correct_answer: B. Tracheo-oesophageal puncture with voice prosthesis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tracheo-oesophageal puncture with voice prosthesis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tracheo-oesophageal puncture with voice prosthesis insertion is the most effective speech rehabilitation method following total laryngectomy, enabling the patient to produce voiced speech.

questions.text: During the postoperative period following a tracheostomy, a patient develops sudden onset of neck swelling and crackling sensation upon palpation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Surgical emphysema.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Surgical emphysema is a complication of tracheostomy characterized by sudden neck swelling and crepitus due to air in the subcutaneous tissue.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with nasal speech and difficulty breathing through the nose. Examination reveals enlarged adenoids obstructing the nasopharyngeal airway. Which term best describes the speech abnormality this patient is likely experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rhinolalia clausa.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinolalia clausa (hyponasality) results from nasal obstruction and is characterized by a lack of nasal speech sounds, as seen in patients with conditions such as adenoid hypertrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following groups of lymphoid tissue comprises the Waldeyer's ring?

options.label: C
options.text: Buccal mucosa, gingiva, floor of the mouth

options.label: D
options.text: Anterior cervical nodes, posterior cervical nodes, submandibular nodes

questions.correct_answer: A. Palatine tonsils, adenoids, lingual tonsils
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Palatine tonsils, adenoids, lingual tonsils.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Waldeyer's ring is a ring of lymphoid tissue in the pharynx, consisting of the adenoids, palatine tonsils, and lingual tonsils, which plays a role in the immune defense of the upper respiratory tract.

questions.text: A surgeon is performing a neck dissection and must be aware of the anatomical structures that pass through the gaps between the pharyngeal constrictor muscles. Which of the following structures passes through the gap between the middle and inferior constrictor muscles?

options.label: A
options.text: Internal laryngeal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal vessels

options.label: B
options.text: Recurrent laryngeal nerve and inferior laryngeal vessels

options.label: C
options.text: Eustachian tube and muscles of the soft palate

questions.correct_answer: A. Internal laryngeal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal vessels
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Internal laryngeal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal vessels.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal vessels pass through the gap between the middle and inferior constrictor muscles and are crucial for sensory innervation and blood supply to the larynx.
  • ➤ internal laryngeal nerve
  • ➤ superior laryngeal vessels
  • ➤ middle and inferior constrictor muscles

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a history of nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and snoring. Examination reveals an open-mouth posture and high arched palate. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adenoid hypertrophy.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenoid hypertrophy is a common cause of nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, snoring, and associated facial changes known as adenoid facies in young children, with a lateral X-ray of the nasopharynx aiding in the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with recurrent sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and snoring. On examination, the tonsils are enlarged, nearly kissing in the midline. Which of the following is the most likely complication that can arise due to the current condition if left untreated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sleep apnea.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tonsillar hypertrophy in children can lead to airway obstruction, particularly during sleep, and is a common cause of pediatric sleep apnea, which can have significant health consequences if not treated.

questions.text: Based on the tympanogram and the clinical presentation of a 6-year-old boy with recurrent upper respiratory tract infections (URTI), poor growth, high-arched palate, and impaired hearing, the most appropriate management would be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In children with recurrent URTIs and associated middle ear effusions, adenoidectomy with grommet insertion can address both the cause and the effect, potentially improving Eustachian tube function and preventing future ear effusions.

questions.text: The instrument used to cut the lower pole of the tonsil during tonsillectomy is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eve tonsillar snare is the instrument specifically designed to cut the lower pole of the tonsil during tonsillectomy.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of profuse epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and recently noted hearing loss. Examination reveals a reddish, fleshy mass in the nasal cavity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA), a benign, highly vascular tumor is seen in adolescent males, characterized by profuse epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and a visible red mass in the nasal cavity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man from Southeast Asia presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, a neck mass, and hearing loss. He reports a history of consuming large amounts of salted fish. An examination reveals palpable cervical lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the oropharynx

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) is associated with risk factors such as EBV infection and consumption of salted fish, which is common in Southeast Asia. It often presents with symptoms like unilateral nasal obstruction, hearing loss, and cervical lymphadenopathy.
  • ➤ Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC)

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient presents with a high fever, severe throat pain, a muffled "hot potato" voice, and difficulty opening the mouth (trismus). On examination, one tonsil is enlarged, and the uvula is deviated to the opposite side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Needle aspiration or incision and drainage

questions.correct_answer: B. Needle aspiration or incision and drainage
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Needle aspiration or incision and drainage.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peritonsillar abscess is characterized by severe throat pain, "hot potato" voice, uvula deviation, and trismus. The most appropriate immediate management is needle aspiration or incision and drainage , followed by antibiotics.
  • ➤ needle aspiration or incision and drainage

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with poor dental hygiene presents with a firm swelling of the neck, elevated tongue, drooling, and difficulty breathing. The patient is febrile and has a muffled voice. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ludwig's angina.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The symptoms and urgency of Ludwig's angina, include fever, firm swelling of the neck, elevated tongue, drooling, and potential airway obstruction, most often secondary to a dental infection. Prompt surgical intervention for incision and drainage, along with antibiotic therapy, is critical for management.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of betel nut chewing presents with a progressive inability to open his mouth and a persistent burning sensation in the oral cavity, especially while consuming spicy food. On examination, pale fibrotic bands are noted in the buccal mucosa. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?

options.label: A
options.text: Discontinue betel nut chewing and start physical therapy for the mouth.

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate surgical intervention for release of fibrosis and skin grafting.

options.label: C
options.text: Biopsy of the buccal mucosa to rule out malignancy.

options.label: D
options.text: Administration of intramuscular steroids and analgesics for symptomatic relief.

questions.correct_answer: A. Discontinue betel nut chewing and start physical therapy for the mouth.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Discontinue betel nut chewing and start physical therapy for the mouth.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial management of oral submucous fibrosis includes discontinuing causative habits, like betel nut chewing, and initiating physical therapy for the mouth to improve trismus. Further treatment may involve pharmacotherapy and, in advanced cases, surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with a painless, bluish swelling in the floor of her mouth, just lateral to the frenulum. On examination, the swelling pushes the tongue upwards. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Plunging ranula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct answer is B) Plunging ranula, as it presents with a cystic, bluish swelling in the floor of the mouth, just lateral to the frenulum, which pushes the tongue upwards.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with bilateral swelling of the parotid glands, fever, anorexia, and body aches. He reports sudden hearing loss in one ear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mumps (viral parotitis)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mumps (viral parotitis), presents with bilateral parotid swelling, fever, anorexia, body aches, and can lead to complications such as sudden sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with pain while eating, particularly when consuming sour or tangy foods. On examination, temporary swelling of the submandibular gland is noted during meals. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sialolithiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sialolithiasis, presents with pain while eating, particularly with sour or tangy foods, and temporary swelling of the affected gland during meals.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a gradually increasing, firm swelling in the tail of her parotid gland. On examination, the swelling is non-tender and mobile. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pleomorphic adenoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pleomorphic adenoma, presents with a gradually increasing, firm parotid swelling, typically occurring in individuals aged 30-40 years.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with a slow-growing parotid mass. Histological examination reveals both mucin-producing cells and squamous cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mucoepidermoid carcinoma, presents with a slow-growing parotid mass and histological examination reveals both mucin-producing cells and squamous cells.
